intro: Semecarpus papuanus, commonly known as the Papuan chestnut, is a tropical tree native to New Guinea. It belongs to the family Sapindaceae and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, clustered flowers. The fruit is a spiny capsule that contains several seeds, which are encased in a hard, woody shell. The plant is often found in lowland and montane rainforests, thriving in humid, shaded environments. Its botanical features make it a distinctive member of the genus Semecarpus.
